name: Dark Vileplume

abilities.name: Hay Fever
abilities.text: No Trainer cards can be played. This power stops working while Dark Vileplume is Asleep, Confused, or Paralyzed.

attacks.name: Petal Whirlwind
attacks.text: Flip 3 coins. This attack does 30 damage times the number of heads. If you get 2 or more heads, Dark Vileplume is now Confused (after doing damage).

flavorText: Perhaps because of their strong-smelling pollen, other Pok√©mon do not approach areas where Vileplumes live.

strengths: Hay Fever completely locks out all Trainer cards
Affects both players - build your deck around it
Can completely shut down Trainer-reliant strategies
Petal Whirlwind can deal up to 90 damage
weaknesses: Very low HP of 60 for a Stage 2
Stage 2 requires setup without Trainer help
counters: Gust of Wind (use before Hay Fever activates)

competitiveHistory: Dark Vileplume was one of the most format-defining cards from Team Rocket. Hay Fever's complete Trainer lock created an entirely new archetype focused on locking out Trainer cards. Decks were built around getting Dark Vileplume into play quickly, then relying on Pokemon abilities and attacks while the opponent struggled without their Trainers. The 'Vileplume Lock' strategy remained relevant for years and influenced deck building significantly.

rulings.ruling: Hay Fever affects both players - neither player can play Trainer cards while it's active.
If Dark Vileplume becomes Asleep, Confused, or Paralyzed, Hay Fever stops working and Trainers can be played again.
Multiple Dark Vileplume in play don't stack - one is enough to lock Trainers.
Petal Whirlwind's self-Confusion happens after damage is dealt and only if 2+ heads are flipped.
